instruction: How did the researchers combine high spatial resolution, geomorphic mapping, and machine learning random forest (RF) classification to accurately map mudflat surfaces?
Output:
The researchers combined high spatial resolution, geomorphic mapping, and machine learning random forest (RF) classification to accurately map mudflat surfaces by using unmanned aerial vehicles (UAV) equipped with RGB and multispectral sensors. The UAV surveys captured high-resolution images with a pixel size of 5 cm. The images were then processed using the structure from motion (SfM) photogrammetric approach to generate orthophotographs and digital surface models (DSM) of the mudflat area.

The researchers identified eight classes of mudflat surfaces based on indexes such as NDVI (Normalized Difference Vegetation Index) and spectral bands normalized to NIR (Near-Infrared). They performed the classification using the random forest (RF) algorithm, a machine learning technique that uses an ensemble of decision trees to classify the data.

To improve the accuracy of the classification, the researchers also incorporated geomorphic mapping. They segmented the DSM into five geomorphic units, which represented different topographic features of the mudflat. The classification was then performed separately for each geomorphic unit using the RF algorithm.
